reviewText: As Stated in the header I am biased but I'll still try to give a accurate account of this trilogy on movies.These movies were shot in the tradition of the Crank movies, fast and a bit shaky camera movement with a heavy dose of humor added even though they are horror movies.Feast One boast a well known but not superstar cast who hang out in a all night dinner/bar located out in the boonies ran by popular seventies actor Clu Gulager then toss in hilarious patrons played by actors/actresses Balthazar Getty. Henry Rollins, Judah Friedlander, Eric Dane, Jenny Wade, Krista Allen and hilarious character actor Duane Whitaker.The first scene opens with a stranger entering into the full bar late at night who is exhausted from running and armed with a gun.He tell the startled patrons if they want to live they must follow his directions.All the while saying this a caption pops up under each character stating their odds of surviving the night and why they have those odds in a hilarious fashion as each person is killed off by creatures who are lurking outside the bar.Although the movie is bloody and graphic in it's violence it's done with a heavy dose of dark humor that will have you laughing as well as cringing at each scene.Feast Two and Three are a continuation of the surviving actors from the previous movie with a touch of new characters thrown in for good bloody measure filmed with the same frenetic and hilarious pace as the first one.It is rare in the movie industry to have a movie be successful and it's follow up films do just as well but this is the case in all three because the same writers and director produced all three thus they all have the same witty dark humor as the previous one.For this reason I gave this three pack 5 stars, something I rarely do.I highly recommend if you enjoy horror movies with heavy doses of dark humor.

reviewText: These three films may be meant to have comedy - but it's very unintentional. They have in common groups of insanely stupid people who in fact kill and injury more people than then monsters do.They don't just wound and injure each other accidentally (shooting off someone's foot, or the like), they do insane things like climb up onto the roof then kick the ladder away - how are they going to get down?The second film features lesbian bikers, one of whom is related to someone killed (accidentally) in the first film. She's more intent in finding the person who did this then staying away from a town full of flesh-eating monsters.Included in this town are two midget wrestlers! One of whom, when he sees the bikers congratulates his brother on "Saving the pussy!" He too is not so concerned about saving his own life.You find yourself thinking that they all deserve to die!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I picked this up because it was Halloween and I thought...why the hell not. I put it in an watched it with a friend of mine b/c we both like cheesy sci-fi/horror films and I suppose in that regard the film did not disappoint. But I mean it never really rises above mediocrity, the creatures aren't overly terrifying, the characters aren't overly memorable.The scenario is pretty run of the mill, a group of people sitting in a bar enjoying a standard night of drinking and pool are interrupted by the ramblings of someone who stumbles in from out of the desert talking about creatures, he is of course dismissed until low and behold the creatures show up and average horror fare ensues.The set up is generic, if you've seen Evil Dead or even The Thing, the premise of people trapped in an isolated location battling creatures is standard. The movie to some extent capitalizes on this by giving us a "rundown" of the characters, where they fall in respective horror genres and their predicted life expectancy. Which I admit I got a good chuckle from, but the rest of the movie just sort of feel flat on itself.The only thing I will say is this, after watching Feast 1, while I admit neither myself nor my friend were overly impressed with the film we were curious as to what happened in Feast 2 & 3. So in that regard the movie is compelling enough to make you want to watch the second and third installments if for no other reason to see what happens to the characters etc which is why I say this is a 3 out of 5.I don't think after watching 1-3 you'll be compelled to watch them again soon, but I suppose for the cost, and what they are we can all just switch off and enjoy some mindless horror films and for that, they're worth keeping on the shelf for that rainy day when you just crave a horror film.Like I said I recommend as a shelf holder and seeing 1 does make you want to see 2 and 3, they're just nothing overly memorable and are average at best.

reviewText: As anyone can clearly tell from the reviews, this bundle (which is three existing DVDs shrink-wrapped together with a sheet of paper bearing the "cover" image rubber cemented to the front -- not a space-saver) only contains the rated cuts of FEAST II and FEAST III. However, TWC has seen fit (finally) to fix this decision by quietly releasing a new DVD. The revised set comes in a single, regular-width DVD case, and all three discs are the Unrated versions. The UPC for that version is 883476028965, and it can be found at many Wal-Marts (right now anyway) for $10. If you want a space-saving, all-Unrated way to get the FEAST movies for cheap, track down that one and pass on this one.
